The question mark is basically saying that if the result is true then that will be the output. Otherwise the output will be what is after the colon.

System.out.println("The value of myBoolean is "+(myBoolean ? "true" : "false")); // If the result is true, the output will be the true. Otherwise it will be false.

What does the question mark stand for?

item.title: Really easy(and stupid) java question
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

Oh, certainly.
A condition operator evaluates an expression giving a different output based on the result.
For example, I’ll make use of a conditional operator in a short program that evaluates the value of a boolean.

public class ConditionalOperators
{
    public static void main(String[] args)
    {
        boolean myBoolean = false; // Declare a boolean with a value of false.
        System.out.println("The value of myBoolean is "+(myBoolean ? "true" : "false")); // If the result is true, the output will be the true. Otherwise it will be false. Since myBoolean is false, the output will be whatever is after the colon which in this case would be "false".
    }
}

Sorry if that was poorly explained, I’m very tired right now.

Read full topic

item.title: Really easy(and stupid) java question
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

You can use a conditional operator.

int playersOnline = PlayerHandler.getPlayerCount();
sendMessage("There "+(playersOnline == 1 ? "is" : "are")+" currently "+playersOnline+" player"+(playersOnline != 1 ? "s" : "")+" online.");

Read full topic
